Does it create problems to add this on other branches? I think this should go to master, 2021* and 2022* branches too.

I do not see any issue in porting this to other branches like 202111 or 202205.

However it is only useful if the product started in production with 201811/201911 and is upgrading to a newer version of SONiC skipping 202012.
Products that started with 202012 or newer will not experience the issue.

I therefore do not believe it's going to be the case and would therefore prefer porting this fix to newer releases unless you believe it's necessary.
Please advise.

201811 to future branch jumps will not be made without first getting to 202012. However, I am not sure about jumps from 201911, in which case we may skip 202012. There isn't enough clarity about that at this point. If there are no concerns, I think replicating fix to other branches will be safest approach.

Hi @StormLiangMS, is the bgpcfgd using zebra? Is it an issue when deleting the loopback interface?
Please see the below scenario, it will warn us when we remove loopback by CLI.

Remove Loopback interface through Config CLI:
```
admin@vlab-01:~$ show ip int | grep Loop
Loopback0                 10.1.0.32/32         up/up         N/A             N/A
admin@vlab-01:~$ sudo config interface ip remove Loopback0 10.1.0.32/32
admin@vlab-01:~$
```
Check Syslog:
```
admin@vlab-01:~$ show logging -f
...
Jun  1 06:13:45.658305 vlab-01 DEBUG bgp#bgpcfgd: Received message : '('Loopback0|10.1.0.32/32', 'DEL', ())'
Jun  1 06:13:45.658305 vlab-01 WARNING bgp#bgpcfgd: Delete command is not supported for 'zebra set src' templates
```

> Hi @StormLiangMS, is the bgpcfgd using zebra? Is it an issue when deleting the loopback interface? Please see the below scenario, it will warn us when we remove loopback by CLI.
> 
> Remove Loopback interface through Config CLI:
> 
> ```
> admin@vlab-01:~$ show ip int | grep Loop
> Loopback0                 10.1.0.32/32         up/up         N/A             N/A

> admin@vlab-01:~$
> ```
> 
> Check Syslog:
> 
> ```
> admin@vlab-01:~$ show logging -f
> ...
> Jun  1 06:13:45.658305 vlab-01 DEBUG bgp#bgpcfgd: Received message : '('Loopback0|10.1.0.32/32', 'DEL', ())'
> Jun  1 06:13:45.658305 vlab-01 WARNING bgp#bgpcfgd: Delete command is not supported for 'zebra set src' templates
> ```

@wen587 
1. bgpcfgd will pass this configuration to zebra to have the source IP for the route. 2. deletion and update is not supported, if the loopback0 interface is removed, currently bgpcfgd will do nothing. And the routes which distributed to kernel would be deleted.

> Do we need to have a test for this?

@prsunny Yes, changed the unit test for this new log changes.

@Ndancejic - bgp is a per-asic service, so it will run for each namespace on multi-asic platform, similar to swss/syncd/teamd/lldp.
So, bgp should be added in multi-asic dependent service list along with teamd.
MULTI_INST_DEPENDENT="teamd"
More details on the issue: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/issues/11653

> @Ndancejic - bgp is a per-asic service, so it will run for each namespace on multi-asic platform, similar to swss/syncd/teamd/lldp. So, bgp should be added in multi-asic dependent service list along with teamd. MULTI_INST_DEPENDENT="teamd" More details on the issue: #11653

@SuvarnaMeenakshi , the concern is by having 'bgp' in MULTI_INST, restarting bgp is also restarting swss whereas ideally we ONLY want the 'vice-versa' behavior. This will be a behavior change from 201911. We don't want swss to be restarted and impacting dataplane when bgp restarts. Infact this is the case today if we restart teamd on a single ASIC devices. @Ndancejic shall raise a github issue for the same. We have to get that reverse dependency fixed before having anything in MULTI_INST.

is sonic-slave still running in emulated environment? for the cross-compiling tool, are they native amd64 binary? in the build process, we still need to run apt-get install, is that running in the emulated mode?

> is sonic-slave still running in emulated environment? for the cross-compiling tool, are they native amd64 binary? in the build process, we still need to run apt-get install, is that running in the emulated mode?

From what i understand, NO, the sonic-slave isn't running in the emulated environment. An apt-get install would still fetch amd64 packages. `<package>:<arch>` extensions have to be provide to install cross architecture packages. 

However, if you mean to ask why do we have to mount `/var/lib/march/docker.sock & /var/lib/march/docker.pid` over `/var/lib/docker.sock & /var/lib/docker.pid`, then it's probably because we have to build the dockers images (which still are arm64/armhf) inside the slave container and it will leverage `/var/lib/march/docker.sock & /var/lib/march/docker.pid` for that purpose 

@gregshpit to confirm if i'm mistaken

> > is sonic-slave still running in emulated environment? for the cross-compiling tool, are they native amd64 binary? in the build process, we still need to run apt-get install, is that running in the emulated mode?

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8035/\#discussion_r726069466

The python wheels need to be installed within target (arm) python virtual environment because they suit for running target python tests, otherwise target python does not find them.

Let me give a bigger picture.
There are two pythons installed in the slave container. The first is regular amd64 and it is installed in /usr/bin/python and another one is target python (armhf/arm64) that is installed inside virtual environment in /python_virtualenv/env3/bin/python. The native amd64 python is used for fast running of different python scripts as part of Sonic build process. The target python is used for (slow using qemu) running tests of the built python wheels that have target debian packages as their dependencies (that's why we need the target python).
The both pythons work fine separately except for a few special case where the installed target python wheels scripts or data are referenced by the absolute path like.
For example in the src/sonic-utilities/config/config_mgmt.py used when running sonic-utilities python tests there is code that loads python script by its absolute path /usr/local/bin/sonic-cfggen:
sonic_cfggen = load_module_from_source('sonic_cfggen', '/usr/local/bin/sonic-cfggen')

This code fails when target sonic_config_engine-1.0-py3-none-any.whl is installed under the virtual environment and sonic-cfggen script is not found in /usr/local/bin/sonic-cfggen but is in /python_virtualenv/env3/bin/sonic-cfggen.
There is a similar case with /usr/local/yang-models python wheel data that is referenced by the absoulute path but is actually installed under the virtual environment.
That was the reason that I linked /usr/local/bin/sonic-cfggen to /python_virtualenv/env3/bin/sonic-cfggen and /usr/local/yang-models to /python_virtualenv/env3/yang-models in slave.mk when these items are installed.

I can suggest the following general and scalable solution (in my opinion) for this link problem. I can introduce 2 new rule.mk variables: _ABS_PATH_SCRIPTS and _ABS_PATH_DATA which can be defined in the .mk files.
For example in rules/sonic-config.mk:
$(SONIC_CONFIG_ENGINE_PY3)_ABS_PATH_SCRIPTS = sonic-cfggen
and in rules/sonic-yang-models:
$(SONIC_YANG_MODELS_PY3)_ABS_PATH_DATA = yang-modules

In slave.mk under cross-compilation if _ABS_PATH_SCRIPTS are defined while the wheel installation then these scripts installed under virtual environment will be linked to the /usr/local/bin/<script>.
If __ABS_PATH_DATA are defined while the wheel installation then these data modules installed under virtual environment will be linked to the /usr/local/.
This will allow transparent access to the absolute (original) python script/data location.

What do you think ?

Thanks,

Gregory

sudo mount --bind $($.gz_FILES_PATH) $($.gz_PATH)/files $(LOG)
sudo mount --bind $(PYTHON_DEBS_PATH) $($.gz_PATH)/python-debs $(LOG)
sudo mount --bind $(PYTHON_WHEELS_PATH) $($.gz_PATH)/python-wheels $(LOG)

Hi @qiluo-msft,

Regarding your last comment https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8035#discussion_r755512074 .
I have already committed a change a week ago that moved common cross-compilation flags to the slave.mk.
So that instead of such old code in src/ethtool/Makefile:

**ifeq ($(MULTIARCH_QEMU_ENVIRON), y)
	DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS=nocheck dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -us -uc -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
else ifeq ($(CROSS_BUILD_ENVIRON), y)**
	_CONFIG_SITE=/etc/dpkg-cross/cross-config.$(CONFIGURED_ARCH) LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$(CROSS_LIB_PATH)_ **DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS=nocheck dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -us -uc -a$(CONFIGURED_ARCH) -Pcross,nocheck -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
else
	dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -us -uc -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
endif**

we now have:

**ifeq ($(MULTIARCH_QEMU_ENVIRON), y)
	DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS=nocheck dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -us -uc -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
else ifeq ($(CROSS_BUILD_ENVIRON), y)
	DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS=nocheck dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -us -uc -a$(CONFIGURED_ARCH) -Pcross,nocheck -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
else
	dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -us -uc -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
endif**

All Makefiles were modified this way. Please take a look in my last commit.
Let me know if this is enough. Note I can't fully remove "**ifeq ($(CROSS_BUILD_ENVIRON), y)**" because in many Makefiles there are some additional commands to be run under cross-compilation flag. LIke in src/snmpd/Makefile:

**ifeq ($(MULTIARCH_QEMU_ENVIRON), y)
	dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -d -us -uc -j1 --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
else
ifeq ($(CROSS_BUILD_ENVIRON), y)**
	sed -i "s/python setup.py/CC=$$CROSS_CC LDSHARED=\"$$CROSS_CC -shared\" python setup.py/g" debian/rules
	sed -i "/opts = NetSNMPGetOpts(\".\/\");/a \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/Makefile.PL
	sed -i "/Params{'LDDLFLAGS'} =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/default_store/Makefile.PL 
	sed -i "/Params{'LDDLFLAGS'} =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/ASN/Makefile.PL	
	sed -i "/Params{'LDDLFLAGS'} =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/OID/Makefile.PL
	sed -i "/Params{'LDDLFLAGS'} =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/SNMP/Makefile.PL
	sed -i "/Params{'LIBS'}    =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/agent/default_store/Makefile.PL
	sed -i "/Params{'LDDLFLAGS'} =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/agent/Makefile.PL
	sed -i "/Params{'LDDLFLAGS'} =/i \$$Params{'CC'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";\n\$$Params{'LD'} = \"$$CROSS_CC\";" perl/TrapReceiver/Makefile.PL
	CFLAGS="-I $$CROSS_PERL_CORE_PATH" LDFLAGS=" -L$$CROSS_PKGS_LIB_PATH" dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -d -us -uc -a$(CONFIGURED_ARCH) -Pcross,nocheck -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
**else
	dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -b -d -us -uc -j$(SONIC_CONFIG_MAKE_JOBS) --admindir $(SONIC_DPKG_ADMINDIR)
endif
endif**

Please provide your feedback.

Thanks,

Gregory

The best idea I have is to pass in the values into the `docker build` command, from `Makefile.work`, with the `--build-arg` argument. The problem with that is the command is run outside of the slave container (on the host server), and `dpkg-architecture` isn't guaranteed to be present on the host server. The next best way to save it to a file and source it for each command that needs those values, but this doesn't seem worth it, so it might not be easy to do this.

For the issue of amd64 python vs armhf/arm64 python and the packages we need to install for being able to test it, here are my thoughts:

Many python packages are arch-independent, because they are just python scripts that are then run through an interpreter at runtime (the interpreter is arch-dependent, since it's an ELF binary). Some python packages have an arch-dependent component to it, where they have some C code that needs to be compiled into a .so library, and that library gets used at runtime. The library is named something like `_module.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so` (with `39` replaced for the python version and `x86_64-linux-gnu` replaced with the GNU triplet of the architecture it's compiled for). Additionally, most python packages from the Debian repos are installed into `/usr/lib/python3` or `/usr/lib/python3.9` (regardless of architecture). For the `*.whl` python wheels we compile in SONiC, a quick check suggests that these wheels just have regular python scripts, and no native libraries.

Within Debian, the `python3.9` and `python3.9-minimal` packages have `Multi-Arch: allowed`, meaning two different architectures of the same package cannot be installed at the same time, but the package compiled for a foreign architecture can be installed if there's no native version of it and there's no better choice (the default is `Multi-Arch: no`, which means two different architectures of the same package cannot be installed at the same time, and the native architecture of the package must be installed). The python standard library (coming from the `libpython3.9-stdlib` package and possibly others) have `Multi-Arch: same`, meaning two different architectures of the same package *can* be installed at the same time.

Given all this, I think it might be possible to use a single (well, mostly single) "copy" of the Python standard library, but just run different interpreters for the architecture we are interested in. To test this out, in a Bullseye slave container (without any changes from this PR), I ran the following commands:

````
dpkg --add-architecture arm64
apt install crossbuild-essential-arm64 libpython3.9-stdlib:arm64 libexpat1:arm64 zlib1g:arm64
````

This will install the binaries needed for doing crosscompilations as well as the python 3.9 standard library, but for the arm64 architecture. In addition, arm64 versions of `libexpat1` and `zlib1g` were installed, since python 3.9 has a dependency on them.

Then, I downloaded the python 3.9 arm64 binaries and extracted them locally:

```
apt download python3.9:arm64 python3.9-minimal:arm64
dpkg-deb -x python3.9_3.9.2-1_arm64.deb tempArm64/
dpkg-deb -x python3.9-minimal_3.9.2-1_arm64.deb tempArm64/
```

Finally, for the native library lookup to work correctly, I had to make a symlink within the `tempArm64` folder to point to the system-wide native library folder:

```
rm -r /root/tempArm64/usr/lib/python3.9/lib-dynload
ln -s /usr/lib/python3.9/lib-dynload/ /root/tempArm64/usr/lib/python3.9/lib-dynload
```

With all this done, I was able to use pip3 to install arm64 python packages:

```
tempArm64/usr/bin/python3.9 /usr/local/bin/pip3 install grpcio
tempArm64/usr/bin/python3.9 /usr/local/bin/pip3 install grpcio-tools
```

and then starting `tempArm64/usr/bin/python3.9` and doing `import grpcio` worked. This didn't require any local compilation because the arm64 precompiled package was used. By default, pip will install packages into `/root/tempArm64/usr/local/lib/python3.9/dist-packages`. I think the `--target` option as part of `pip3 install` can be used to install it into a different directory, but I haven't tried this.

Given all of this, I think it's possible to not manually precompile some python 3 packages, and to install the python wheels that we compile for the SONiC build globally instead of a local virtualenv. This might also remove the need to having special handling for the config engine script path and the yang models directory path.

UPDATE: Know problem.
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/10097

I think that the correct way to set libmonit_cv_setjmp_available and libmonit_cv_vsnprintf_c99_conformant variables is to pass them to the configure script by modifying debia/rules file like this (under cross-compilation build):

```
override_dh_auto_configure:
        dh_auto_configure -- \
                --sysconfdir=/etc/monit libmonit_cv_setjmp_available=yes \
                libmonit_cv_vsnprintf_c99_conformant=yes
```

So there is no need to modify /etc/dpkg-cross/cross-config.cache file.
I'll check this approach once monitor git is up again.

> Hi @saiarcot895, Regarding [#8035 (comment)](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8035#discussion_r816139094). I've never created patches. Can you please briefly explain how to create a patch. There are 10 files that should be changed under cross-compilation build. How do I create such patch. Thanks,

The easiest starting point might be to use quilt. The basic steps would be to unpack the sources (which should already be done by the build system), and then do the following (from the source directory that was just unpacked):

```
quilt init
# Make a new patch
quilt new cross-compile-changes.patch
# Add files that need to be changed, so that quilt grabs the current version of the file first
quilt add debian/rules
# Make your changes now
vim debian/rules
# Refresh/Generate the patches
quilt refresh
# Optional: Unapply the patch
quilt pop
```

Those steps would create a patch in `patches/cross-compile-changes.patch`, which can then be copied out, and our Makefile can apply it. You should be able to find some guides online on using quilt.

I rewrote cross-build-arm-python-reqirements.sh as you suggested and it works fine. Thanks.
See the new script below. Please approve it.

```
#!/bin/bash

PRE_BUILT_TARGET_DIR=$1

declare -a pkgs=("grpcio==1.38.0" "grpcio-tools==1.20.0" "m2crypto==0.36.0" "bitarray==1.5.3" "lxml==4.6.3")

rm -rf $PRE_BUILT_TARGET_DIR && mkdir $PRE_BUILT_TARGET_DIR
rm -rf python-cache && mkdir python-cache

for pkg in "${pkgs[@]}"
do
        CC=$CC pip3 install --cache-dir python-cache $pkg
        CC=$CC pip install --cache-dir python-cache $pkg
done

find python-cache -name "*.whl" -exec cp {} $PRE_BUILT_TARGET_DIR \;
```

Considering that the script isn't doing anything more than installing the package and saving the wheel, and [this](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8035/files#diff-6b0c1444ee324b0a060487f8cfefdf2c451bec1b699a653e6f7430b761d9f5e7R96) line in the diff is already doing that, I don't think this needs to be a separate script, since there's no prebuild happening anymore. Additionally, I don't think it's necessary to save the downloaded wheel anymore, since it can be just downloaded when it's needed.

> You also wrote that you think it is possible "to install the python wheels that we compile for the SONiC build globally instead of a local virtualenv. " , you mean to install them in /usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages ? But how then armhf python3 installed either in virtual env. or under /root/tempArmhf or under any directory other than /usr/bin/ will find the no-arch SONIC python packages installed under /usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages ? Please elaborate.

The symlink created in [this](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/8035#issuecomment-1054595427) comment will tell the armhf/arm64 python 3 binary to search for python packages/wheels in the global/standard directory, in `/usr/lib/python3.9/`:

```
rm -r /root/tempArm64/usr/lib/python3.9/lib-dynload
ln -s /usr/lib/python3.9/lib-dynload/ /root/tempArm64/usr/lib/python3.9/lib-dynload
```

Therefore, there's no virtualenv needed.

Also, right now in your diff, all of the python packages being installed in the slave container are specified on one line in the Dockerfile (in the case of the cross-compile build). I would rather have it be specified where they're already currently specified, so that it's easier to see why it's being installed, and so that it's not one giant line.

> However for arm python I also need to install its own arm modules in a location different than the system location to avoid overriding system python modules, correct ?

After looking further into this, the answer is yes and no.

For Python 2, Python modules that are installed through `apt` will not result in files getting overwritten (the pure python scripts will be "overwritten" when installing an arm64 version on top of amd64, but the contents should be the same, since it's just a text file). The native libraries (`.so`) will include a multiarch triplet in the name that describes the architecture (for example, `_dbus_bindings.x86_64-linux-gnu.so`), and the Python binary coming from Debian will check for a library with the multiarch triplet first before checking for one without the triplet.

However, for packages installed via pip (and Python packages in SONiC), the native libraries will not have a multiarch triplet, which means that if the amd64 version of some package was installed via pip, and then the arm64 version of the package gets installed, then that could result in some shared library file getting overwritten, and functionality could be broken for one of the two architectures (depending on which gets installed last).

Because of this, virtualenv (or maybe telling `pip` to use a different installation directory for packages that it installs instead of the default `/usr/local/lib/python2.7/`)) may be needed for Python 2.

For Python 3, the shared libraries for all python packages (except maybe some python modules being built in SONiC; this can be fixed) include the multiarch triplet in the name (for example, `etree.cpython-37m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so`). This means that there is no overwriting of files that should happen (`.py` files should be arch-independent, and thus the same across architectures).

Because of this, I don't think using virtualenv is needed for Python 3.

The issue that this then brings up (applicable to both Python 2 and 3 outside virtualenv) is that pip itself doesn't know when the amd64 version of a python wheel is installed and when the arm64 (or armhf) version of a python wheel is installed. The only idea I have for this is to have a custom directory where pip installs its packages, and add that to the site packages list for python (this can be done through the `sitecustomize.py` file).

> This means that when sonic-cfggen is installed this line is replaced with the location of the python that installed it (this is what happens).

This may actually work well for our purposes. If the arm64 python is used to run pip and to install packages, then the shebang line should point to the arm64 python binary. For example, when running `tempArm64/usr/bin/python2.7 /sonic/target/python-wheels/buster/sonic_config_engine-1.0-py2-none-any.whl`, the shebang line in `sonic-cfggen` points to the arm64's python binary:

```

"""sonic-cfggen

A tool to read SONiC config data from one or more of the following sources:
minigraph file, config DB, json file(s), yaml files(s), command line input,
and write the data into DB, print as json, or render a jinja2 config template.

Examples:
    Render template with minigraph:
        sonic-cfggen -m -t /usr/share/template/bgpd.conf.j2
```

The Sonic image now uses a Bullseye base image, so if you set `NOBULLSEYE=1`, you will not be able to build the Sonic image. This also means that the changes you did for the slave containers would need to be done for the Bullseye slave container.

Note that there is some work being done to move the containers to be based on Bullseye (instead of Buster), which means at that time, the Buster slave container probably won't be used.

I compared my build to the Sonic pipelines and looks like we are doing the same build steps. Is there importance of the host ubuntu workstation on which I'm running bullseye build ? Is Ubuntu 16.04 too old for building bullseye ?

Thanks,

Gregory

For the image build command, most people would just be doing `make configure PLATFORM=marvell-armhf PLATFORM_ARCH=armhf` followed by `make target/sonic-marvell-armhf.bin`. Even though the base image is Bullseye, some containers are based on Bullseye, whereas others are based on Buster; in other words, Buster containers are built first, then Bullseye containers are built, and finally the Bullseye base image with the Buster and Bullseye containers is assembled. This also means that to build a sonic image, `NOBUSTER` must be set to 0, since there is still Buster-related stuff built.

`BLDENV` is the Debian version used for the current "stage" of the build. You shouldn't be explicitly setting this unless you're calling `Makefile.work` directly.

For the slave container error you're hitting, the host version shouldn't matter, since this is all within a container (the possible exception being QEMU being involved for running armhf/arm64 binaries, in which case the host system's glibc could have an impact). Can you look for the first package that failed to be configured and see what the error there was? That package failing is probably causing all of the dependent packages to fail to be installed.
